btw:definition.p: Etymologically linked to the process of sedimentation (pra√sad, see below), prasāda denotes the resulting state of clarity and translucency of liquids. This sense is extended metaphorically to human states of mind, emotion, and attitudes, thus lending to prasāda its most common meanings of serenity, confidence, and favor or mercy.

In Buddhist literature, prasāda belongs mainly to the semantic field of faith. Within this field, two senses are discernible: confidence or faith, and reverential devotion. In the first case, prasāda denotes, depending on the context, either an intuitive sense of trust, aroused by the sight of Buddha or a brief encounter with his teachings, or the complete confidence that derives from deep understanding of the dharma. In both cases, it also conveys the sense of reassurance and serenity associated with profound conviction. In the sense of devotion, it denotes a sudden and overpowering surge of faith towards the Buddha or his disciples, accompanied by strong emotion, and typically manifested as a devotional impulse to make offerings, receive precepts, or take vows.

btw:example.btw:tr: Chatterjee 65-67Of these, śraddhā means the well-grounded belief in the law of moral causation (karma), truths (āryasatyas) and the ratnas (Buddha, dharma & saṃgha – the tri-ratna); it is the clarity (of the mind) and the desire of the mind. Śraddhā proceeds in three ways – (one) in the form of belief in the things that are real, the virtuous (beneficial) and the non-virtuous. (The other ) in the form of the purity (clarity of the mind) in regards to the real and the virtuous. (The third) in the form of desire for what is possible to obtain or to cultivate in regard to the real and the virtuous. (To explain) the purity of the mind. Śraddhā by virtue of its being opposed to (or curative to) the impurity (restlessness) of the mind an as such by way of application (association) thereof, the mind having been free fom kleśa or the elements of moral defilement, upakleśa or the vicious elements of limited occurrence, lla or impurities, kāluṣya or excitement (restlessness) realises śraddhā an thus gets purified and as such it is called purity of the mind. This functions in the form of providind the (necessary) basis for chanda or desire.

btw:example.btw:tr: Which constituent factor (dharma) is called ‘inner tranquillity’ (adhyātmasaṃprasāda)? Inner tranquillity is the peaceful flowing of one’s mental series that derives from the dissociation from the agitation of gross and subtle reasoning (vitarka and vicāra). Just like a river is agitated with waves, the mental series unfolds disturbed (aprasannā) because it is agitated with gross and subtle reasoning. But, if it is so, it (i.e. inner tranquillity) is not a distinct entity, so how can there be eleven entities? Because [the entity] ‘faith’ coincides with confidence (prasāda): After attaining the second meditative stage, the meditator experiences the arising of the complete assurance that he can leave (niḥsaraṇa) the samāhitabhūmi. This is inner tranquillity; according to others, neither inner tranquillity nor gross and suble reasoning and meditative concentration (samādhi) are distinct entities (dravyāntara)

btw:example.btw:tr: Chatterjee 89-90āśraddya or the fculty of disturbed mind means the unsettles belied in the law of moral causation (karmaphala), the truth (the four noble truths) and in the ‘ratnas (the three fold ratnas – the Buddha, the dharma nad the samgha) as opposed to śraddhā or the faculty of settled mind. Śraddhā means the sttled belief in the reality (of moral causation ), the clarity of understanding (unstained attitude) in regard to the effectiveness (of the four Noble truths) and longing for the accessibility (of the three ratnas). ‘Āśraddhā’ being opposed to that means non-belief in the reality (of moral causation) non-clarity of attitude to the effectiveness of the truths and non-desire for the accessibility (of the ratnas). It functions in the form of of providing scope for langour (kausīdya). It is said to be providing scope for langour in the sense that one lacking ‘śraddhā’ has no determination to employ oneself in action.

btw:example.btw:tr: by virtue of skillful means, the perfumer Gupta had converted (abhiprasādita) in the teaching of the Venerable One. when the [perfumer] had been converted, the elder [Śāṇakavāsin] went to his house, one day accompamied by many monks, on another day with another person only, and yet another day, he went alone. so, upon seeing that the elder Śāṇakavāsin was alone, the perfumer Gupta asks ‘Why, Your Reverence is not accompanied by an accolite?’ The elder said: ‘Why should a decaying mortal have accolites? If [, though,] some people, driven by faith (śraddhāpuruga) were to renounce worldly life they would be my accolites.’ The perfumer said: ‘Your Reverence, all my life (tāvad) I have been coveting the householder’s life and have been attached to the pleasures of the sense; I cannot renounce worldly life. But I shall devote my son to be the accolite of Your Reverence.’

btw:tr.p: Now eventually, through skillfull means, Gupta the perfumer came to be favorably disposed toward the Teaching of the Blessed One. One day, after this had happened, the elder Śāṇakavāsin went to his house along with many monks; then, on another day, he went there with only one other monk; and, on a third day, he went there all alone.
When Gupta saw that the elder Śāṇakavāsin was all by himslef he asked:
“How is it the the Noble One has no attendant?”

“ Why,” replied the elder, “should we, who are subject to old age, have any attendants? If someone, moved by faith, should be initiated into monastic life, then he would truly be a attendant and a followers of ours.”

“ Noble One” said the perume merchant, “I have always been greedy for the householder’s life and taken delight in the field of the senses; it is not possible for me to be initiated into the monastic life. However, when I have a son, I will give him to your lordship as an attendant”.

atha rājā sthavirānandena praśādavegāvarjitacittasantatiḥ | sthavirāna(1)ndasamīpam upagamya sarvaśarīreṇa sthavirānandasya pādayor nipatitaḥ | utthāya ubhe jānumaṇḍale pṛthivyām upanikṣipya prasādaromāñcakarkaśīkṛtamūrtiḥ kṛtakarapuṭaḥ sthavirānandam abhiṣṭotum ārabdhāḥ | […] idañ citrataraṃ manye śrāvakeṇa satā tvayā | mahākāruṇikenaiva yat sattvārthaṃ mahat kṛtaṃ
dṛṣṭvā ca punaḥ karṇasya sārthavāhasyātimahāprasādo jātaḥ ||

sa mahatā prasādavegena vipaśyinaḥ samyaksambuddhasya pādayor nipatya mahatā svareṇa praṇidhānaṃ kartum ārabdhaḥ | anena dvipadāṃ śreṣṭha dāneneha virūpatāṃ | adya prabhṛti saṃtyajya labheyāhaṃ surūpatāṃ |1| suvarṇavarṇavāso ’ti haimavarṇair viguṇṭhitaḥ | candanotpalagandhaś ca kāyād vaktrāc ca me bhavet |2| suvarṇavarṇasaṃkālaḥ sarvalokamanoharaḥ | sarvāmayavinirmuktaḥ sarvaśāstrārthapāragaḥ |3| sarvavācāthasaṃyuktaḥ sarvānarthavivarjitaḥ | sarvottamaḥ sarvadarśī sarvākāravibhūṣitaḥ |4| sarvārthasiddhaḥ sambuddho bhaveyaṃ sattvavatsalaḥ | sarvāmalaguṇaḥ śrīmān sarvadravyānvitaḥ sukhī |5|
athaitad upaśrutya karṇaḥ sārthavāhaḥ sahasaiva sahasraiḥ prasādakaṇṭakitasarvaromakūpaḥ kṛtāñjalir vipaśyinaṃ tathāgataṃ muhur muhur namasyamānaḥ

atha karṇaḥ sārthavāho gṛham āgato bhāryayā cāsya hṛṣṭatuṣṭapramuditayā sauvarṇena bhṛṅgāreṇārgham anupradattaṃ | uktaś cāryaputra tvatpuṇyānubhāvād īdṛśaḥ kenāpi bhavanavaram abhinirmitam ity atha karṇaḥ sārthavāhas taṃ bhavanavaram abhivīkṣya paramaprītisaumanasya jātaḥ sutarāṃ buddhe bhagavati utpannaprasādopajanitaromāñcaḥ śirasi kṛtakarapuṭāñjalir namas tasmai bhagavate tathāgatāyārhate samyaksambuddhāyācintyācintāmaṇaye ’nuttarāya puṇyakṣetrāyety uktvā praharṣapūrṇavadanakamalaḥ prāha ||

atha karṇaḥ sārthavāhas tīvraprasādavegāvarjitacittasantatiḥ saṃlakṣayati | bhagavantam āgamya mayaivaṃ vibhūtir āsāditā yan nv ahaṃ prathamato bhagavantaṃ vipaśyinaṃ tathāgatam asmin gṛhe praveśya saśrāvakagaṇaṃ bhojayeyam iti viditvā mahatā satkāreṇa vipaśyinaṃ tathāgataṃ saśrāvakasaṃgham antargṛhe upanimantrya śatarasenāhāreṇa saptāhaṃ bhojayitvā pādayoḥ praṇipatya yāvajjīvaṃ sarvopakaraṇaiḥ pravāritavān |
surendrāsurendroragaiś ca bhaktyā prasādena nityavandyasya
tac chrutvā bhṛtakapuruṣaḥ prasādakaṇṭakitaḥ sahasaivotpannātidurllabhapratibhānas tam uvāca ||

ahaṃ cāścaryaprasādapratilabdhas tasya satpuruṣasya caraṇau praṇamya śatasahasramūlyaṃ muktāhāraṃ kaṇṭhād avatārya dadāmi || sa taiḥ muktāhāraṃ na pratigṛhṇāti sma | tam aham etad avocam: pratigṛhyemam, yatra te prasādo bhavati tasmai prayaccheti |

p.foreign: tau dṛṣṭvā rājā hasitaḥ / imau śrāmaṇerau bālakrīḍayā krīḍataḥ yāvad rājñā bhikṣusaṅghaṃ pariveṣya vṛddhāntamārūḍhaḥ / sthavireṇa cānuyuktaḥ / mā devena kutracid aprasāda utpādita iti / rājāha / neti / api tu asti dvau śrāmaṇerau bālakrīḍayā krīḍayo yathā bāladārakāḥ pāṃśvāgāraiḥ krīḍantyevaṃ tau śrāmaṇerau saktukrīḍayā krīḍataḥ khādyakrīḍayā krīḍataḥ / sthavira uvāca / alaṃ mahārāja / ubhau hi tau ubhayato bhāgavimuktau arhantau / śrutvā ca rājñaḥ prītimanaso buddhirutpannā / tau śramaṇerāvāgamya bhikṣusaṅghaṃ paṭenācchādayiṣyāmi / tatastau śrāmaṇerau rājño 'bhiprāyamavagamya bhūyo 'nye 'smābhiḥ svaguṇā ubhdāvayitavyā iti [cintitau] / tayorekena kaṭāhakā upasthāpitā dvitīyena raṅgaḥ samudānītaḥ / rājñā pṛṣṭau śrāmaṇerakau / kimidamārabdhaṃ / tayorabhihitaṃ / devo 'smākamāgamya bhikṣusaṅghaṃ paṭenācchāditukāmaḥ / tān paṭān rañjayiṣyāmaḥ / śrutvā ca rājño buddhirutpannā| mayā kevalaṃ cintitaṃ na tu vāṅa niścāritā| paracittavidāvetau mahātmānau| tataḥ sarvaśarīreṇa pādayornipatyaṃ kṛtāñjaliruvāca|

btw:tr.p: The king laughed. “ These two novices are playing the games of children”, he observed and having now finished serving the entire community, he returned to the elders’ end. There, Yaśas asked him: “ did your majesty see anything at all that raised doubts in his mind about the community?” “ No” replied the king,” however, I did see two novices who were playing children’s games. Just as young boys play ar building houses in the dirt, so these two were playing at games of ground meal and cakes.” “Say no more, great king,” said the elder,” both of these novices are arhats who are free from both physical and mental defilements!” Upon hearing this, Aśoka rejoiced in his heart and resolved to present to these two novices his offering of cloth for the community. The novices immediately divined the king’s intention and said: “ Let us make his merit even more numerous.” One of them therefore set ip a cauldron and the other begin to prepare dye. “ What is your undertaking?” the king asked them. “ Your majesty”, they answered,” has approached us with the desire of presenting an offering of cloth to the community of monks; we will dye the cloth.”” I never said anything about this,” Aśoka reflected, “ but only thought it. These two can read other people’s mind!” And immediately he fell full length at their feet, made an ñjali and said:

lg.l: the Mauryan, who sacrificed
what it was good to sacrifice
in order to attain what it is good to attain
today has such faith in you, good people,
that he resolutely makes this offring
along with his servants, his court,
and the citizen of his capital.”

btw:example.btw:tr: Rajapatirana ??"To every man that is born, an axe is born in his mouth, by which he cuts himself when speaking bad language. He who praises him who is to be blamed, and blames him who is to be praised, accumulates evil with his mouth, by which evil he finds no joy. Trifling is this evil that one should lose his wealth by dice; here, this is a greater evil that one should corrupt his mind against the Sugatas. For they are a hundred thousand Nirarbudas, and thirty-six and five Arbudas, to which hells he who blames an Ārya goes, having employed his speech and mind sinfully. Through corruption of the mind beings go to evil states of existence; by serenity of mind beings go to good ones."

btw:etymology.p: synonymous Av. *had and PIE *ē̆s- (Pokorny) / *sed (Rix). Conjoined with pra, the verb probably alludes to the process of sedimentation, by which particles in water sink down leaving the water clear, pure and translucent. The noun prasāda, too, signifies clarity and tranquility by metonymic contiguity; since clearness is the result of sedimentation and calm (in liquids). Metaphorically, it also denotes the tranquility derived from belief as well as a positive disposition towards others or towards an object or a religious teaching. By metonymical contiguity, it signifies the result of such a disposition: a favorable attitude, offerings and favors; by extension, it includes also devotion and overpowering feelings of faith, which perhaps do not imply tranquility (by most Western preconceptions). Since the meaning of clarity coexisted with that of faith, exegetes liked to explain cetasaḥ prasāda as mental clarity derived from confidence in the Buddhist doctrine.

Cp. Eng “settle down,” “to be set in one’s convictions;” also “sedate,” which goes back to Lat sēdō –are, “to settle, soothe, calm, allay,” and its partic. sēdātus, “calm, composed,” adv. sedate. Consider also sedimentum.
